newsitem.title: JORDAN: World Bank to lend Jordan $120 million.
newsitem.headline: World Bank to lend Jordan $120 million.

text.p: The World Bank is set to approve a $120 million loan for Jordan to expand a social safety net for its poor during IMF-guided structural reforms, an official from the bank said on Tuesday.
"Jordan has recently successfully negotiated the loan and it should be going to the (World Bank's) board soon for approval," a World Bank official told Reuters.

Inder Sud is currently reviewing with Jordanian officials progress in existing World Bank programmes undertaken in the kingdom, including a $40 million export development loan approved last March, the bank official said.
Jordan launched a three year IMF-directed structural reform programme in 1996 building on successful monetary stabilisation since an economic crisis in 1989 wiped out its reserves.
The current plan includes privatisation of state utilities, an overhaul of economic laws to boost foreign investment, development of the domestic capital market and major stock market reform.
But the government is under pressure in the wake of riots which flared after it doubled bread prices under the IMF-sanctioned plan. Unemployment and poverty were widely blamed for the bread riots
Officials say the World Bank and the IMF have pledged support to expand a safety net for Jordan's poor during the reforms to prevent social upheaval.

In the aftermath of the riots Jordan pledged a two-pronged policy of encouraging private sector investment and reinforcing a safety net to cushion Jordan's poor -- a majority of its 4.2 million population -- during the transition period.
The government says it is pushing ahead with laws to boost export industries and attract foreign investment to create jobs.

The World Bank says 15 percent of Jordan's population are below the absolute poverty line. Officials say 18 percent of the 900,000-strong labour force is unemployed but economists believe unemployment is at least 25 percent.
World Bank aid until mid-1996 covered 10 projects totalling $500 million, which are still in progress. Total lending commitments since 1962 have approached $1.4 billion, the official said.

The bank is extensively involved in every sector of the Jordanian economy and its current loans include an $80 million agriculture loan to help farmers switch to higher value crops, health schemes and developing infrastructure in poorer areas.
